description: Cisco ASA Express Security refers to the firewall product line that comes from Cisco. This course prepares the viewers for the Cisco ASA Express Security exam (500-260), which covers basic firewall configuration as well as the new features found in Cisco FirePOWER (formerly FireSIGHT) and is commonly required for Cisco Channel Partners that are selling and promoting Cisco Adaptive Security Appliances (ASA). One should attain the knowledge to at least be able to take an ASA out of the box, configure it to a network, get it filtering traffic and successfully get FirePOWER enabled and running. The knowledge one can attain in the CCENT and CCNA can serve as a great foundation base when learning about Cisco ASA.
name: Cisco ASA Express Security
subtitle: Next Generation Firewall

episodes.description: This course prepares the viewers for the Cisco ASA Express Security exam (500-260). The exam covers basic firewall configuration as well as the new features found in Cisco FirePOWER (formerly FireSIGHT). This exam is commonly required for Cisco Channel Partners that are selling and promoting Cisco Adaptive Security Appliances (ASA).
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:09.038
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:09.038 --> 00:00:09.844
In this video,

3
00:00:09.844 --> 00:00:14.130
we're gonna take a look at the Cisco ASA
Express Security course here on ITProTV.

4
00:00:14.130 --> 00:00:17.120
Now if you're not familiar with
ASA Express Security, well,

5
00:00:17.120 --> 00:00:20.490
it's really referring to the firewall
product line that comes from Cisco.

6
00:00:20.490 --> 00:00:23.570
And they don't like to call them firewalls
anymore, they call them adaptive security

7
00:00:23.570 --> 00:00:27.096
appliances because they can do so
many different things.

8
00:00:27.096 --> 00:00:30.140
And the ASA Express Security course is
a great one because it gives you a high

9
00:00:30.140 --> 00:00:33.810
level view of all the crazy features
that are available inside of ASAs and

10
00:00:33.810 --> 00:00:35.320
some of the different things
that we can do with it.

11
00:00:35.320 --> 00:00:36.730
It's a really neat course.

12
00:00:36.730 --> 00:00:39.680
I know I'm excited about it, not just
because it's a good course, but because

13
00:00:39.680 --> 00:00:42.520
I've got a very special friend here in
the studio to help us go through and

14
00:00:42.520 --> 00:00:43.450
learn about all this.

15
00:00:43.450 --> 00:00:48.040
We've got Cisco book author and all around
knowledgable Cisco guy, Todd Lindley,

16
00:00:48.040 --> 00:00:49.090
here in the studios with us.

17
00:00:49.090 --> 00:00:50.120
Todd, thanks for being here.

18
00:00:50.120 --> 00:00:51.560
>> It's great to be here.

19
00:00:51.560 --> 00:00:55.130
So, what made me wanna come back to
the studio, cuz we had just done FirePOWER

20
00:00:55.130 --> 00:00:57.290
based on when my book came out,
right, the FirePOWER.

21
00:00:57.290 --> 00:00:58.380
So we're gonna cover that.

22
00:00:58.380 --> 00:01:02.320
But we already have a course on that and
a full, detailed course.

23
00:01:02.320 --> 00:01:04.770
But I got a lot of calls from
Cisco partners and reps.

24
00:01:04.770 --> 00:01:10.160
And they were saying, hey, we've got
to get certified on a certain test,

25
00:01:10.160 --> 00:01:14.420
the Cisco ASA Express Security 500-260,
to be able to sell with the FirePOWER.

26
00:01:14.420 --> 00:01:17.470
So not a lot of people were
able to teach FirePOWER today.

27
00:01:17.470 --> 00:01:21.660
So getting the pods and the curriculum and
all of that, so I've got that capability.

28
00:01:21.660 --> 00:01:26.380
So I've been doing a lot with that and I
thought I need to add this as a supplement

29
00:01:26.380 --> 00:01:31.630
to the course ware and to the book and
to our existing course.

30
00:01:31.630 --> 00:01:34.970
Let's, because on that course we did
there, Don, it was a very great course.

31
00:01:34.970 --> 00:01:40.020
Extreme detail of FirePOWER, best video
course in the world, I think, right?

32
00:01:40.020 --> 00:01:41.502
>> It was very technical too.

33
00:01:41.502 --> 00:01:43.330
It's like if you hadn't worked with ASAs,
and

34
00:01:43.330 --> 00:01:47.310
you went right into that FirePOWER course,
you'd get over your head pretty quickly,

35
00:01:47.310 --> 00:01:52.460
so it's pretty obvious that we needed
some kind of middle ground in between,

36
00:01:52.460 --> 00:01:54.840
what would consider like a-
>> Stepping stone approach.

37
00:01:54.840 --> 00:01:56.530
So we can take a stepping
stone approach and

38
00:01:56.530 --> 00:01:59.500
configure the ASAs,
start at the beginning.

39
00:01:59.500 --> 00:02:02.120
And we're gonna act like you've
never seen an ASA before, right,

40
00:02:02.120 --> 00:02:04.940
we're gonna talk about naming
an interface cuz we gotta name it.

41
00:02:04.940 --> 00:02:08.420
We're gonna create objects, the access
list, but one of the things you and

42
00:02:08.420 --> 00:02:10.370
I were having a conversation about.

43
00:02:10.370 --> 00:02:14.600
Yeah, we're starting at the beginning with
the ASA, but we have some pre-requisite

44
00:02:14.600 --> 00:02:18.890
knowledge base that we think you should
have, and I'll let you go into that.

45
00:02:18.890 --> 00:02:20.350
>> Sure, yeah.

46
00:02:20.350 --> 00:02:24.100
If you've worked with firewalls a lot,
then you may not even need this.

47
00:02:24.100 --> 00:02:25.640
You may be able to jump
right into FirePOWER, but

48
00:02:25.640 --> 00:02:28.220
if you've never worked with them, you've
gotta get into that initial configuration.

49
00:02:28.220 --> 00:02:29.393
And that's where we kick things off,
right?

50
00:02:29.393 --> 00:02:31.700
We're just getting things
set up like that, but

51
00:02:31.700 --> 00:02:34.851
we're not gonna spend a lot of
time on fundamentals and theories,

52
00:02:34.851 --> 00:02:37.570
things like IP subnetting or
basic routing principles.

53
00:02:37.570 --> 00:02:39.880
And those are things that they would
kind of expect you to already have.

54
00:02:39.880 --> 00:02:42.340
So a lot of the people that are gonna
watch this course are people that have

55
00:02:42.340 --> 00:02:45.300
already been through like a CCENT or

56
00:02:45.300 --> 00:02:48.310
a CCNA that at least have that
basic knowledge in place.

57
00:02:48.310 --> 00:02:49.930
To then be able to take it and

58
00:02:49.930 --> 00:02:52.990
apply it to the firewalls because a lot
of these concepts aren't new, right?

59
00:02:52.990 --> 00:02:55.080
Access control list,
that's not a new concept,

60
00:02:55.080 --> 00:02:56.550
you've probably seen it in routers.

61
00:02:56.550 --> 00:02:57.680
Now we're gonna see it in firewalls.

62
00:02:57.680 --> 00:03:00.210
And it's really just
a different set of commands.

63
00:03:00.210 --> 00:03:01.890
>> Right, so
we're gonna see in the new code and

64
00:03:01.890 --> 00:03:04.850
how we do access control lists,
we're not gonna go into it.

65
00:03:04.850 --> 00:03:08.000
You're gonna understand that hey,
at the end of this access control list,

66
00:03:08.000 --> 00:03:11.700
there is a permit IP, or
deny IP any any, right?

67
00:03:11.700 --> 00:03:14.410
So, we're not gonna mention that,
we're gonna assume things like that.

68
00:03:14.410 --> 00:03:16.420
We're not gonna go into
any routing protocols.

69
00:03:16.420 --> 00:03:21.800
I'll do some static routing on the ASAs
just for my little network here, but

70
00:03:21.800 --> 00:03:28.710
also NAT, I think, and VPNs,
right, something outside the CCNA.

71
00:03:28.710 --> 00:03:34.040
So we're still gonna assume you have
a CCNA level access or knowledge of NAT.

72
00:03:34.040 --> 00:03:37.714
And we're gonna talk about how it's done
on the new code, it's called Object now or

73
00:03:37.714 --> 00:03:39.800
ObNAT, very cool, very cool stuff.

74
00:03:39.800 --> 00:03:42.300
>> All right, well, we've talked about
the knowledge we expect them to have.

75
00:03:42.300 --> 00:03:44.483
Let's talk a little about the knowledge
that we're gonna give them, right?

76
00:03:44.483 --> 00:03:45.360
>> Yeah.
>> So,

77
00:03:45.360 --> 00:03:47.800
let's take a look at that outline and
see some of the things we're gonna cover.

78
00:03:47.800 --> 00:03:48.435
>> All right.

79
00:03:48.435 --> 00:03:52.765
So, again, so
we got the Express Security 500-260.

80
00:03:52.765 --> 00:03:55.285
And we're gonna kind of focus
on those objectives, and

81
00:03:55.285 --> 00:03:58.565
we're going to get into here's an ASA,
let's start at the beginning.

82
00:03:58.565 --> 00:04:01.655
Cuz we're talking about security levels
on the interface, stuff like that.

83
00:04:01.655 --> 00:04:05.805
And so it's the 500-260 exam,
is the objectives that we're covering.

84
00:04:05.805 --> 00:04:11.370
And we're gonna also talk about FirePOWER,
but we're not gonna go in as much detail

85
00:04:11.370 --> 00:04:15.650
as we did in the actual FirePOWER class,
cuz we don't need to for these objectives.

86
00:04:15.650 --> 00:04:19.330
However, by the end of this course,
you'll take an ASA out of the box,

87
00:04:19.330 --> 00:04:23.080
configure it for your network,
install FirePOWER, put policies on, and

88
00:04:23.080 --> 00:04:24.590
put it into production network.

89
00:04:24.590 --> 00:04:28.680
That's our goal by the end of this course.

90
00:04:28.680 --> 00:04:31.350
So we have an introduction ASA,
what they are, talk about the products and

91
00:04:31.350 --> 00:04:34.180
the licensing and
high availability, and so on.

92
00:04:34.180 --> 00:04:38.340
Initial configuration is when we get
into the IP interfaces, the naming

93
00:04:39.960 --> 00:04:45.090
and security levels, and
then we talk about ACLs,

94
00:04:45.090 --> 00:04:48.470
and how they're a little bit simpler,
I think, than an iOS, actually.

95
00:04:48.470 --> 00:04:54.360
And then the nuggets is the same as NAT,
but we talk about how we create objects.

96
00:04:54.360 --> 00:04:58.130
We'll demonstrate creating objects and
how those are used within a NAT statement.

97
00:04:58.130 --> 00:04:59.500
It's also refered to auto-NAT.

98
00:04:59.500 --> 00:05:02.670
All right now, one of the things
is as we go through this,

99
00:05:02.670 --> 00:05:04.910
we're gonna go through quite
a few episodes before.

100
00:05:04.910 --> 00:05:06.222
You know on the Command Line and

101
00:05:06.222 --> 00:05:10.160
then we're gonna get into something called
ASDM, which is the GUI that we use today.

102
00:05:10.160 --> 00:05:11.720
That's certainly changing this year,

103
00:05:11.720 --> 00:05:15.880
we're gonna get a new GUI to configure
the ASA and FirePOWER all in one, right?

104
00:05:15.880 --> 00:05:18.320
So we're gonna see that
coming out shortly.

105
00:05:18.320 --> 00:05:21.000
But this is going to cover the ASDM.

106
00:05:21.000 --> 00:05:23.980
And we're gonna see that,
we're gonna kinda walk through that.

107
00:05:23.980 --> 00:05:25.500
I don't use it very much,

108
00:05:25.500 --> 00:05:29.270
so I'm gonna probably be looking around
a little bit as we're going through there.

109
00:05:29.270 --> 00:05:31.810
But the section after that is the VPNs,
and

110
00:05:31.810 --> 00:05:36.270
that's where I do a lot of ASTM because
it does all this work for you in there.

111
00:05:36.270 --> 00:05:38.510
And VPNs can be extremely detailed.

112
00:05:38.510 --> 00:05:40.816
So that's when we use ASDM,
but before that,

113
00:05:40.816 --> 00:05:43.700
pretty much everything
else is done from the CLI.

114
00:05:43.700 --> 00:05:46.600
After that, we're gonna get into
the FirePOWER and talk about what,

115
00:05:46.600 --> 00:05:49.930
when you get an ASA, how do I make
the FirePOWER module come up and

116
00:05:49.930 --> 00:05:52.720
how do I create policies and
we'll go through the different policies,

117
00:05:52.720 --> 00:05:56.530
the file policy, IPS store policy,
and the access control policy.

118
00:05:56.530 --> 00:05:58.850
And that's kind of our
goal with this course,

119
00:05:58.850 --> 00:06:00.644
to follow along with the exam objectives.

120
00:06:00.644 --> 00:06:05.180
>> Yeah, so key thing to remember here
is that we're gonna spend some good time

121
00:06:05.180 --> 00:06:08.750
talking about FirePOWER, it's a very
powerful, very advanced feature.

122
00:06:08.750 --> 00:06:10.450
And if you're just starting
out with this show,

123
00:06:10.450 --> 00:06:12.650
then you're gonna get a chance
to see what it can do.

124
00:06:12.650 --> 00:06:15.885
But if you really wanna dig into
the nitty gritty details and

125
00:06:15.885 --> 00:06:19.075
see all the things that source fire
can do, remember that we've already

126
00:06:19.075 --> 00:06:22.355
filmed a Sourcefire series and
you can jump right over and watch that.

127
00:06:22.355 --> 00:06:24.195
If you've never worked
with a firewall before,

128
00:06:24.195 --> 00:06:26.940
I don't recommend you jumping
right into that other course.

129
00:06:26.940 --> 00:06:28.450
Watch this one first, and
then you'll be set up and

130
00:06:28.450 --> 00:06:29.901
ready to jump into the other one and
be a success.

131
00:06:29.901 --> 00:06:33.494
>> Right, cuz we're gonna introduce the
FirePOWER module and we do it there, but

132
00:06:33.494 --> 00:06:36.710
I'm still gonna do more of a high
level overview on this one.

133
00:06:36.710 --> 00:06:38.344
But we're gonna stop using
the word Sourcefire.

134
00:06:38.344 --> 00:06:39.800
[LAUGH], all right, so.

135
00:06:39.800 --> 00:06:41.080
>> You gotta say FirePOWER.

136
00:06:41.080 --> 00:06:42.890
>> The name, yeah,
by the time you're watching this,

137
00:06:42.890 --> 00:06:46.510
whenever you're watching this, Cisco's
just renaming this thing FirePOWER, right,

138
00:06:46.510 --> 00:06:47.830
so it's just FirePOWER.

139
00:06:47.830 --> 00:06:50.250
And so Sourcefire's gone,
that was the company they bought.

140
00:06:50.250 --> 00:06:54.258
So we'll talk about that in a bit
when we get to that episode.

141
00:06:54.258 --> 00:06:56.888
>> All right, so once we've moved
through FirePOWER, we get, I mean,

142
00:06:56.888 --> 00:06:58.011
no, I got it right this time.

143
00:06:58.011 --> 00:06:59.693
Shoot, I got [CROSSTALK]
>> You did!

144
00:06:59.693 --> 00:07:03.420
>> So once we get through FirePOWER,
it's been Sourcefire for so long.

145
00:07:03.420 --> 00:07:06.790
Once we get through that,
we get a high level view of what it does,

146
00:07:06.790 --> 00:07:08.880
we move through that,
we see it, we're successful.

147
00:07:08.880 --> 00:07:12.690
We're ready to basically go back into
our organization, and at a minimum,

148
00:07:12.690 --> 00:07:17.050
be able to take an ASA out of the box,
turn it on, get it filtering traffic, and

149
00:07:17.050 --> 00:07:19.270
get FirePOWER enabled and up and running.

150
00:07:19.270 --> 00:07:22.120
>> Yeah and one of the approaches that I
wanna take here is obviously, I had so

151
00:07:22.120 --> 00:07:24.440
many calls about this exam that
I wanted to focus on that.

152
00:07:24.440 --> 00:07:26.570
So I called this guy and say,
hey, I'm doing all these classes.

153
00:07:26.570 --> 00:07:31.020
Let me come down there and film this as
a supplement for those courses, and again,

154
00:07:31.020 --> 00:07:33.918
you're gonna use the other
FirePOWER training for

155
00:07:33.918 --> 00:07:36.590
if you're in production
as a supplement for that.

156
00:07:36.590 --> 00:07:39.870
In this case here, we remember that
the very beginning, if you've already

157
00:07:39.870 --> 00:07:43.660
configured ASAs for many years, then this
course, the beginning of it isn't for you.

158
00:07:43.660 --> 00:07:45.400
You just go over to the FirePOWER course.

159
00:07:45.400 --> 00:07:48.300
This is geared toward someone I
haven't really seen in ASA course.

160
00:07:48.300 --> 00:07:52.740
I don't see a lot of ASAs where they start
at the beginning like we're gonna start.

161
00:07:52.740 --> 00:07:55.190
And then configure it all
the way through to FirePOWER and

162
00:07:55.190 --> 00:07:56.500
putting it into production.

163
00:07:56.500 --> 00:07:59.350
So that's what we're gonna do,
step by step by step by step.

164
00:07:59.350 --> 00:08:02.340
>> All right well,
if all that sounds interesting to you,

165
00:08:02.340 --> 00:08:04.520
I know it sounds interesting to me,
you're in the right place.

166
00:08:04.520 --> 00:08:06.550
Stay tuned, those episodes are coming up.

167
00:08:06.550 --> 00:08:07.910
If it doesn't sound interesting to you,

168
00:08:07.910 --> 00:08:09.770
if it sounds like it's a little
over your head, don't worry.

169
00:08:09.770 --> 00:08:11.180
We've got the CCENT,

170
00:08:11.180 --> 00:08:14.090
CCNA training that kinda serves as
that foundation available on the site.

171
00:08:14.090 --> 00:08:15.640
You can jump right over and
start to watch that,

172
00:08:15.640 --> 00:08:18.010
and then jump back over
here when you're ready.

173
00:08:18.010 --> 00:08:22.943
But for those of you who are sticking
with us, stay tuned because we've got

174
00:08:22.943 --> 00:08:26.872
our Cisco ASA Express Security
shows coming up after this.

175
00:08:26.872 --> 00:08:34.854
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode Todd and Don introduce the viewers to the Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance product line. Afterwards, Todd demonstrates the initial configuration of an ASA to get it up and running.
episodes.title: Introduction to ASA

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd and Don walk through the initial steps to configure an ASA for production deployment. Todd starts by manually performing the basic configuration from the first episode. He then demonstrates the firewall actively blocking traffic.
episodes.title: Initial Configuration

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd and Don continue with the initial ASA configuration. Todd demonstrates the final steps of an initial configuration and then explains how to configure protocol inspection to allow Ping and Traceroute to function.
episodes.title: Initial Configuration Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd and Don complete the initial configuration of a Cisco ASA firewall. Todd demonstrates how to allow traffic through the firewall using access lists. He then completes the configuration by configuring network address translation.
episodes.title: Initial Configuration Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd and Don demonstrate using the Cisco Adaptive Security Device Manager (ASDM) to perform the initial configuration of an ASA. Todd shows each of the steps from the previous episodes inside of the GUI.
episodes.title: ASDM

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd and Don explore using virtual private networks (VPN) to secure network traffic. Todd starts with Clientless SSL VPNs and finishes up with Cisco AnyConnect VPNs.
episodes.title: VPNs

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd demonstrates how to perform the initial configuration of a SourceFIRE FirePOWER module. He explains how service policies are used to direct traffic to the SourceFIRE model, and introduces the users to the FirePOWER web based user interface.
episodes.title: FirePower Configuration

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd introduces users to the initial policies required for FirePOWER to begin functioning. He demonstrates creating System and Health Policies as well as how to apply them to managed devices.
episodes.title: System and Health Policies

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd demonstrates how to implement and configure file policies. File policies allow the end users to filter what files are denied or allowed to pass through the FirePOWER module.
episodes.title: File Policies

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd and Don cover Intrusion Prevention System (IPS) policies in Cisco FirePOWER. Todd explains the default policy and how it is used by FirePOWER. Next, Todd demonstrates how to customize the policy to eliminate false positives on your network.
episodes.title: IPS Policies

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd introduces the viewers to Access Control Policies in Cisco FirePOWER. He demonstrates creating a custom access control policy and then walks the viewers through each of the customization options available.
episodes.title: Access Control Policies

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd continues demonstrating Access Control Policies in Cisco FirePOWER. He explains how rules are defined in an ACP and then demonstrates creating and configuring a rule set to match a customer's needs.
episodes.title: Access Control Policies Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Todd wraps up the FirePOWER section with a few final configuration settings. He starts by explaining device discovery in the FireSIGHT Management Center. He ends the episode by demonstrating how to schedule maintenance tasks within the FSM.
episodes.title: Discovery and Scheduling
